text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Bryce Roni that's right I am
very excited to show you my take on the
dish created by and for people that
can't quite decide whether they want
rice or pasta and before we get started
I just have to say I've lived in San
Francisco for over 30 years and the next
time I have this served to me in town
will be the first time so I'm not
exactly sure where that famous tagline
came from but be that as it may this is
still quite a delicious side dish and as
you'll see very easy to make so with
that let's go ahead and get started with
our top-secret spice blend which will
include some salt some freshly ground
black pepper some celery salt paprika
coriander tumeric some dry mustard and
last but never least some cayenne pepper
sure we could add those one at a time to
the pan but when we have this made add I
always think it's easier to do ahead of
time and then just toss any ones and
then once that set we'll head over to
this stove where we're gonna melt 2 or 3
tablespoons of butter over medium high
heat in a pan that's at least 3 or 4
inches deep and has a tight-fitting lid
that's kind of important here and then
once our butter starts to melt and
bubble we'll go ahead and add our diced
onion but we're not gonna saute that
alone this time
because to that we're gonna add our
pasta and what I like to use this orzo
also known as melon seed pasta which I
think looks cool and works very nicely
in this but if you wanted to break up
some spaghetti into small pieces that
would also work and is probably the more
popular choice and what we want to do
for the next few minutes is cook this
mixture stirring until our onions soften
and turn translucent but much more
importantly our pieces of pasta toast to
a beautiful golden brown and by the way
all those little pieces of pasta are not
gonna cook at the same rate ok so some
are going to get a little darker than
others but that's all part of the show
and I'll pretty much keep this on medium
high but if you want you could back it
down to medium which is going to take a
little longer but might be a little
safer so just if need be that's just you
cooking
and then what we'll do once we've
determined our pastas cooked to the
perfect golden brown which for me was
right here we'll go ahead and toss in
our top secret spice blend and stir that
in and cook that for I don't know about
30 seconds or so just to sort of wake up
those flavors in that hot fat and then
once we've stirred in our spices and
cook that for about a half a minute we
can go ahead and add our white
long-grain rice and stir that in and the
rice we're not gonna Brown we are only
gonna stir that around long enough where
we think all those grains of rice are
coated with the butter which is only
gonna take about a minute or so just be
careful the rice does like to fly out of
the pan yes I did edit that part out but
anyway we'll go ahead and stir in our
rice and once we're pretty confident
it's been coated with all that goodness
we'll go ahead and add our chicken broth
and you know how sometimes I tell you
you can use water instead this time you
can't okay you really do want to use a
nice rich stock or broth for this we did
that video and we're actually gonna put
in less than one would assume okay a
two-to-one ratio is fairly standard but
in my opinion way too much liquid okay
that's when things get mushy and sticky
so we're going with the one to
one-and-a-half ratio which I think works
out way better but anyway we'll stir
that in and wait for it to come up to a
simmer
at which point we'll give it one last
stir before reducing our heat to low
covering it and letting it cook covered
for exactly 17 minutes okay no stirring
no peeking
which is why these glass lids are cool
you can peek any time you want without
screwing it up and what we'll do once
our timer rings after exactly 17 minutes
is turn off the heat and let it sit just
like that for exactly five minutes okay
don't touch the lid just let it sit
there and then what we'll do once our
timer rings after five minutes is take
off the lid add some finely and freshly
chopped Italian parsley and then fluff
it with a fork okay we want to fluff
this and fluff it good and what we're
doing here is releasing a lot of that
residual heat so it doesn't overcook but
we're also at the same time breaking up
any clumps so all our grains of rice and
pasta are nicely separated and while I'm
doing this I should mention if you want
you can add other stuff to this okay
things like green peas or diced
vegetables
shredded chicken garbanzo beans so
accessorize this as you see fit you are
after all DeCarlo mini Oni of your
rice-a-roni and then once our mixture
has been thoroughly forked and fluffed
it is pretty much ready to eat except of
course for the traditional taste right
you may need to adjust with more salt a
lot of thats going to depend on how
highly seasoned your broth was but mine
was perfect so I went ahead and served
it up and then there are some side
dishes you want to transfer into some
kind of beautiful serving dish and then
there's others like this that you just
want to serve right out of the pan
it just seems more appropriate and I
finished up with a little pinch of
parsley I noticed on the cutting board
and that's it what I'm calling
rice-a-roni is done take that trademark
infringement lawyers I'm still probably
going to get a letter but it will all
have been worth it because this really
is delicious and remarkably close to
that stuff they call the San Francisco
treat and if you're wondering is it
really that tasty well not quite but
there's three good reasons for that M s
and G which this does not contain but
having said that I really love how this
comes out and there's something to be
said for being able to pronounce all the
ingredients in it and this is really not
that much harder to make than this stuff
from the store but anyway that's it what
I'm calling rice-a-roni
if you'll excuse me I'm gonna go hang
out waiting for my cease and desist
letter but in the meantime I really do
hope you give this a try soon so head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
you
